Suez

Springfield, Massachusetts

Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility



RMP Executive Summary



Suez (formerly United Water) has implemented a comprehensive program to safely manage chlorine at the Springfield Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility (SRWTF) located in Agawam, Massachusetts. There have been no chlorine incidents in the most recent five year period or in the history of the plant.  



An RMP/PSM Compliance Manual was initially developed for the site in 2001, and is continually reviewed updated as needed or required by regulation. 



Key items included in the manual are:



- Written site-specific procedures for Employee Involvement, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Pre-Startup Safety Reviews and Self-Audits;



- Chlorine and process safety information as required by the regulations;



- Standard Operating Procedures for chlorine management; and



- Chlorine system maintenance procedures.



The following additional steps were implemented to complete the prevention program:



- Training on PSM/RMP and its key components including Management of Change, Mechanical Integrity and Incident Investigation;



- Conducting Process Hazards Analyses for the chlorine process at least every 5 years; 



- Conducting a Compliance Audit at least every 3 years

 

- Developing an Emergency Response Plan; and 



- Training in support of the certification of operators.

          

The Suez Project Manager and select employees are meeting several times per year to review and update procedures and to maintain compliance with all aspects of the PSM/RMP regulations.



In addition to Process Safety Management and Risk Management, the organization has an active safety program. The SRWTF has an active Employee Safety Committee that is a joint management-employee committee.  The committee meets monthly and its duties include reviewing new safety procedures, accident investigations, safety surveys and safety communications.



At the Wastewater Plant, t

here are safety tailgate meetings attended by all employees, to review an OSHA subject or discuss a safety issue.  Routine training is conducted for topics such as:



- Hazard Communication



- Personal Protective Equipment



- Lockout/Tagout



- Confined Space

 

As a result of these programs, the SRWTF should continue to enjoy an excellent safety record. As mentioned earlier, there have been no reportable chlorine releases from the plant.  The plant has worked extensively to upgrade its safety program.                                                                                         



Report by:



Mickey Nowak

Assistant Project Manager
